com.j2speed.async
Class SyncRunner

java.lang.Object
  com.j2speed.async.SyncRunner
All Implemented Interfaces:
AsyncRunner
public final class SyncRunner
extends java.lang.Object
implements AsyncRunner

An "asynchronous" runner that uses the calling thread to execute the asyncs. This runner is useful to build synchronous version of an asynchronous API.

Author:
Alex Nistico <alienisty(at)gmail.com>

start

public final AsyncRun start(Async async,
                            CompletionHandler... handlers)
Description copied from interface: AsyncRunner
Asynchronously invokes the specified Async.

Note that if the passed Async also implements CompletionHandler, it will receive call-backs notification from the computation.

This feature is provided as a convenience to allow the use of a single instance to define the computation and the call-backs, making the syntax neater when used as an anonymous class, eg: 

 runner.start(new AsyncCompletion() {
   @Override
   public void run(State state) {
     // do something
   }
   @Override
   public void complete() {
     // do something else
   }
   @Override
   public void onException(Throwable exception) {
     // handle problems
   }
   @Override
   public void onFinally() {
     // do something at the very end
   }
 });
Note that, except for Async.run(State), not all other call-backs are necessary, you can only use the one you want to act on.

Specified by:
start in interface AsyncRunner
Parameters:
async - the Async to be started.
handlers - CompletionHandlers registered to handle call-backs from the computation.
Returns:
The AsyncRun instance for the started Async.

start

public final <T> AsyncRun start(Request<T> request,
                                ResponseHandler<T>... handlers)
Description copied from interface: AsyncRunner
Asynchronously invokes the specified Request.

Note that if the passed Request also implements ResponseHandler, it will receive call-backs notification from the computation.

This feature is provided as a convenience to allow the use a single instance to define the execution and the handling of the response, making the syntax neater when used as an anonymous class, eg: 

 runner.start(new AsyncResponse<String>() {
   @Override
   public String run(State state) {
     // do something
   }
   @Override
   public void onResponse(Result<String> response) {
     // do something else
   }
   @Override
   public void onException(Throwable exception) {
     // handle problems
   }
   @Override
   public void onFinally() {
     // do something at the very end
   }
 });
Note that, except for Request.run(State), not all other call-backs are necessary, you can only use the one you want to act on.

Specified by:
start in interface AsyncRunner
Type Parameters:
T - the type for the requested value.
Parameters:
request - the Request instance to run.
handlers - ResponseHandlers registered to handle call-backs from the computation.
Returns:
The AsyncRun instance for the started Request.

start

public final <T> AsyncRun start(Progressive<T> request,
                                ProgressHandler<T>... handlers)
Description copied from interface: AsyncRunner
Asynchronously invokes the specified Progressive.

Note that if the passed Progressive also implements ProgressHandler, it will receive call-backs notification from the computation.

This feature is provided as a convenience to allow the use a single instance to define the execution and the handling of the progress, making the syntax neater when used as an anonymous class, eg: 

 runner.start(new AsyncProgress<String>() {
   @Override
   public String run(ProgressState state) {
     // do something
   }
   @Override
   public void onProgress(Progress<String> response) {
     // do something else
   }
   @Override
   public void complete() {
     // do something else again
   }
   @Override
   public void onException(Throwable exception) {
     // handle problems
   }
   @Override
   public void onFinally() {
     // do something at the very end
   }
 });
Note that, except for Progressive.run(ProgressState), not all other call-backs are necessary, you can only use the one you want to act on.

Specified by:
start in interface AsyncRunner
Type Parameters:
T - the type for the requested value.
Parameters:
request - the Progressive instance to run.
handlers - ProgressHandlers registered to handle call-backs from the computation.
Returns:
The AsyncRun instance for the started Progressive.
